Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Novel Microwave Based Plasma System for Analytical Atomic Spectrometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will generate crucial analytical spectroscopy data and analytical instrument optimization required for the successful commercialization of an innovative microwave-induced plasma (MIP) technology for atomic spectroscopy analysis. This technology promises to have a significant impact on trace elemental analysis by providing a low-cost, portable, widely-applicable alternative to the current standard inductively coupled plasma (ICP). With portable technology now approaching 30% market share, the $4 billion global atomic spectroscopy market is poised to undergo a major change. The proposed MIP innovation will continue to drive the growth of this market by providing the first portable solution with analytical performance approaching that of a tabletop unit. The new level of flexibility will allow trace elemental analysis in applications and locations where it would not have been previously considered. The societal impact of this differentiating technology empowers end users, rather than large laboratories, with a means to quantify their environmental footprint through the analytical measurement and in-situ monitoring of low level of metals in samples. The ongoing introduction of new and stricter environmental and safety regulations in most developed and developing nations will ensure that this market need will only grow over time.

The intellectual merit of this project derives from an innovative, multidisciplinary, and collaborative approach to a long standing technical challenge of creating a purely inductive plasma at microwave frequencies. Materials science, electromagnetic fields, plasma physics, and analytical chemistry all play an important role in the proposed solution where a copper coil is replaced by a ring made of advanced technical ceramic. The ceramic material, an almost perfect insulator at low frequencies, is a nearly ideal medium for microwave dielectric polarization currents. These currents generate a pure inductive field in MIP, leading to an ICP-like plasma at microwave frequencies, where lower losses, cost, size, and power requirements make the portability possible. The resulting toroidal plasma exhibits robustness to sample loading and analytical zones directly comparable to standard ICP. The proposed project includes the development, characterization, and optimization of the new MIP in a collaboration between a small business and a renowned academic institution. The research is expected to generate reliable MIP performance metrics for trace elemental analysis and to assess the susceptibility of MIP to interferences or matrix effects in order to validate the proposed commercial positioning for a portable MIP optical emission spectrometer product.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The most recent crisis in Flint, Michigan has brought to public attention the issue of water infrastructure fragility and quality control.  Drinking water is a basic yet scarce human necessity that we so easily take for granted. The national crisis that has unraveled exposed how minute amounts of certain metals lead to health risks to children and infants, as first afflicted victims, followed by adults with longer exposure times.  Concentration levels of 15 parts per billion are considered actionable levels affecting human health. To make matters worse, the analysis has found that 100s of schools and daycare centers have repeatedly failed these tests over the last 3 years.

What are the measurement techniques that can detect such small quantity of metals in water on the order of parts per billion? How is it possible to continuously monitor metals in the drinking water of the general public, schools, daycare centers, hospitals, clinics, and our homes? The instruments required to measure metals at such low concentration levels are highly precise analytical tools established by high end research laboratories over the last several decades.  The standards set by EPA reflect laboratory techniques and tools uniquely understood and analyzed by highly qualified analytical chemists.  Reproducing this type of work in the field, at schools, daycare centers, at well sites in a continuous and monitored basis is currently not feasible due to the elaborate infrastructural demands on the instrumentation required to produce such highly sensitive readings.

Radom Corporation has invested in developing a transformational technology to make these instruments available for use on site, at any site. Utilizing the very same techniques prescribed by the EPA and world renowned research labs, Radom is re-inventing and re-engineering the technology into a portable form factor. The enabling innovation, patented by Radom in 8 major world markets, is based on remarkably low power losses in Advanced Technical Ceramics. By reducing the power losses in the instrument a hundred-fold, the instrument is not only made radically smaller but, more importantly, there is no longer any need for specialty gases, such as argon, the primary factor which has kept the current state-of-the-art instruments tied to the lab.  

The support provided by the NSF SBIR Phase I grant was critical in enabling Radom to move the technology from the development lab into the hands of users who had the sophisticated expertise and the equipment required to perform performance evaluation in analytical chemistry applications. The key objective was to establish the most important performance metrics of direct relevance to the end user. The NSF SBIR funds have allowed Radom to install the technology at the Indiana University Lab for Spectrochemistry, where analytical chemistry experts, with Radom’s support, were able to set and demonstrate new performance levels: less than part-per-billion detection limits across many chemical elements, unparalleled tolerance to organic solvents, and tolerance to total dissolved solids of 25% compatible with the most demanding applications.   

This achievement, partly funded by the NSF and co-researched at Indiana University has led for the first time to a feasible instrument that can continuously operate in the field and deliver the sensitive results required at local sites.  This instrumentation may be remotely run on sites at schools, daycare centers, geological sites, environmental disaster sites and in general public to continuously monitor water quality for the detection of multiple highly toxic metals including lead (Pb), Mercury (Hg), Chromium (Cr), Cadmium (Cd), Copper (Cu) and Arsenic (As), to list a few.
